FacilityName: Carlsbad Municipal Water District Maerkle Facility

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The chlorine systems at Carlsbad Municipal Water District (MWD) are used for the treatment of potable water used for distribution to the City of Carlsbad.  Chlorine is stored as a liquefied compressed gas in typical one-ton containers at the Carlsbad MWD stations.  Two chlorine systems are situated on the Carlsbad MWD site: Lower Maerkle, and Upper Maerkle.  As stated on their website, "Carlsbad Water Operations Departmnet is responsible for a variety of behind the scenes services that keep our city running smoothly. We are "At Your Service" and committed to providing top quality service to the Carlsbad community."



Carlsbad MWD's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Water Operations Superintendent is responsible for various inspections of the City's facilities to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.



Carlsbad MWD has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current.



Carlsbad MWD has formal and informal facility training

programs for all employees.  Hazardous Materials training, (Awareness Level, 8-Hour HAZWOPER), is given to operators at the district.  These operators are allowed to go onsite and assess a potential release from outside.  All employees receive generalized training during new employee orientation.  The level of additional training may vary depending upon the department to which an employee is assigned.  Operators are trained to call for outside assistance (911 and/or San Diego HazMat) to respond to a chlorine release.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Carlsbad Municipal Water District Maerkle Dam facility (5203 Sunny Creek Road, Carlsbad, California) is owned and operated by Carlsbad MWD (5950 El Camino Real, Carlsbad, California).  The facility is located approximately 1 mile north of the intersection of El Camino Real and Palomar Airport Road.  The area surrounding the facility consists of the Maerkle reservoir, agricultural land, and a new residential development to the North.  Two very similar chlorine water treatment systems reside on the property: Lower Maerkle and Upper Maerkle.  The chlorine systems were constructed in 1995 accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.  Each process is located within a separate chain link fenced area with access through one gate only.



The Maerkle Dam Stations Facility is a 111 acre site that consists of a ten million gallon distribution reservoir, a 600 acre foot long-term storage impound, one pumping/disinfection facility (Lower Maerkle), one impound disinfection facility (Upper Maerkle), related pressure control stations, meter stations, and a caretaker's residence.  The site is normally unmanned (with the exception of the caretaker's residence).  Operators visit the site daily to ensure that the chlorine systems are operational.



** Lower Maerkle Dam Station



A maximum of five (5) one-ton containers of chlorine can be stored in the chlorine room at any one time.  Empty co

ntainers are also stored in the chlorine room until being picked up by the chlorine vendor during the next chemical delivery.



Two (2) one-ton containers are on-line at any one time where one is in operation and the other is on standby.  The on-line containers are each placed on a digital scale that indicates the remaining weight of chlorine in each of the on-line one-ton containers to allow system operators to monitor usage and plan ahead for ordering more chlorine.  The chlorine system is operated entirely under vacuum conditions with a vacuum regulator attached to each of the one-ton container valves.  Each one-ton container is positioned so that the valves are vertically aligned.  The flex tubing is connected to the top container valve to ensure that chlorine gas (not liquid) is drawn out of the container.  

 

Chlorine gas is drawn from operating on-line one-ton container through an automatic switchover / vacuum regulator.  The automatic switchover regulator valves control which container is actively feeding chlorine to the vacuum regulator.  A vacuum (negative pressure) is created when process water is pumped through the injectors.  This flow generates a vacuum which opens the vacuum regulator.  Upon loss of vacuum in the line downstream of the vacuum regulator, a diaphragm in the vacuum regulator will close, stopping any chlorine from escaping from the line under vacuum.  Any chlorine in the piping upon loss of vacuum (downstream of the vacuum leak) will be drawn to the injection point and into solution.



Downstream of the vacuum regulator, chlorine is fed to a combination of six manually-adjustable chlorinators located in an adjacent room.  The chlorine can be distributed to four independently-controlled processes: System 20, System 30, and System 40.  Each process feeds chlorine gas into solution at an injector where it is mixed with water.  System 20 is flow paced only - the chlorine feed rate is manually controlled at the rotameter.  The other three

systems are compound loop systems - the chlorine feed rate is controlled by a combination of manual adjustment at the rotameter and residual chlorine concentration.  The feed rate at the four independent processes is based on the free total ammonia and flow residual at the outlet.  The facility is manually adjusting the feed rate and is checking the feed rate on a daily basis.



A monorail hoist is used to change out the chlorine cylinders.  The SCADA system also provides a readout of the weight of the one-ton containers that is on-line; however, the facility uses the reading from the digital scale for the weight readout.



Fuse plugs on the one ton containers are the main relief system for the chlorine equipment.  Fuse plugs are designed to yield and melt between 158F and 165F to relieve pressure and prevent rupture of the container in case of fire or other exposure to high temperature.  



The one-ton containers are stored in the Chlorine Tank Room, which is protected by a scrubber with a capacity of 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  The scrubber is activated based on the alarm status of a chlorine leak detector located in the Chlorine Tank Room.  



** Upper Maerkle Dam Station



The maximum quantity of chlorine maintained for the Upper Maerkle Dam Station process is 2 one-ton containers (4,000 pounds).



The design and operation of the chlorine system (upstream of the chlorinators) at the Upper Maerkle Dam Station is essentially identical to that of the Lower Maerkle Dam Station.  Only two chlorinators are used at the Upper Maerkle Dam Station.  Prior to injection, the chlorine gas passes through a chlorine dioxide generator that used sodium hypochlorite as a reagent to create chlorine dioxide.  The process feeds this chlorine dioxide into solution at the injector where it is mixed with water.  Similar chlorine detection and scrubber systems are located at the Upper Maerkle Dam Station.    





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTI

ON STEPS



The Carlsbad MWD chlorine systems have many safety features.  Much of the systems' safety is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern their operation.  For example, the Carlsbad MWD treatment processes operate in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of chlorine, there are four mechanisms in the facility to minimize the impact: 1) chlorine gas detectors, 2) visual/audible alarms, 3) emergency chlorine scrubber system, and 4) halogen automatic shut-off valves.  



There are two chlorine detectors located in the chlorine room where one only provide a redundant displays located in the adjacent rotameter rooms at the Upper Maerkle Station and the Lower Maerkle Station.  At 1ppm, it activates an audible alarm and sends a call through the SCADA system to the Duty Operator's phone then to the backup Duty Operator.  At 3ppm, the audible and visual alarms are activated, the halogen valves are triggered to automatically close the one-ton container valve (via a motorized mount), the scrubber is activated, the ventilation system that continuously circulates the air in the chlorine building shuts off, and the SCADA system sends another message to the Duty Operator that the halogen valve was activated.  



The halogen valves consist of a motorized mechanism mounted on each vacuum regulator that is designed to close the ton container valve in the case of a chlorine leak detection.  There is also a battery which provides enough power to close the valve during a power loss.



The scrubber runs until the detector senses a 1 ppm chlorine concentration in the chlorine storage room; meaning it can only be manually shut off when the concentration is lower than 1 ppm.  The scrubber for each facility has a capacity to scrub 2,000 pounds of chlorine with a 99%+ r

ate of effectiveness.



In the event of a power failure, vacuum regulators prevent chlorine from escaping the system.  A backup generator that is activated during a power outage is maintained onsite to power the chlorine systems.  If vacuum conditions are compromised, the vacuum regulators close to stop chlorine flow from the one-ton containers.  Chlorine vent lines are piped to ventilation intakes of the scrubber system.



Fuse plugs on the one ton containers are the main relief system for the chlorine equipment.  Fuse plugs are designed to yield and melt between 158F and 165F to relieve pressure and prevent rupture of the container in case of fire or other exposure to high temperature.  



There is also a panic button located in the Chlorine Dioxide Generator Room at the Upper Maerkle Dam Station and in the Chlorine Tank Room at the Lower Maerkle Dam Station.  Activating the panic button will close the halogen valve.



In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices recommended by the Chlorine Institute.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the Carlsbad MWD Upper and Lower Maerkle Dam Stations' accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (April 10, 2014), there have been no significant releases of chlorine at the both the Upper and Lower Maerkle Dam Stations that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10

pounds in the last five years (April 2009 to April 2014) or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of hazardous material for the Five-Year Accident History at the facility.   In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Carlsbad MWD has an emergency plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document, which is maintained at the facility and updated as necessary.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



  1.)  To save lives.

  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.)  To protect the environment.

  4.)  To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.



Carlsbad MWD has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, Carlsbad Fire Department.  Since the facility is normally unmanned, chlorine operators are typically the only personnel on site.  In case chlorine leak detection at the facility, the on-call ("duty") operator is alerted via SCADA system to operator's phone.  The duty operator alerts the MWD Supervisor and immediately responds to the alarm.  Upon arrival, the Supervisor will determine whether or not the Fire Department is to be called to respond to the emergency based on the severity of the incident.  The duty operator assignment is made on a rotating basis between the 5 chlorine systems operators.  Each

chlorine operator has the necessary hazardous materials training to be considered "qualified" to assess the severity of a chlorine leak.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation performed on April 10, 2014 and the Seismic Assessment Revalidation performed on April 10, 2014 provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Carlsbad MWD facility located at 5203 Sunny Creek Road in Carlsbad, California.  The Revalidation was comprised of one session that included a discussion of any changes to the chlorine systems since the previous HAZOP Revalidation study, a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the 2009 PHA Revalidation study, a discussion of the facility's accident history dating back five years, the completion of chlorine checklists, and the completion of the HAZOP log tables.  The recommended changes are scheduled to be completed by April 2015.  The Seismic Assessment Revalidation was comprised of a walkdown of the facility and the completion of the Seismic Equipment and Piping Walkdown Checklists provided by the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health.



In addition, the facility is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for Carlsbad Public Works employees.  These include the following items:



1.  Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.



2.  Continue to have employee involvement in updating and refining Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.



3.  Continue employee involvement through the Employee Participation program.



4.  Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
